name: Acne
description: Acne is a common skin condition characterized by pimples, blackheads, whiteheads, and sometimes cysts. It often occurs on the face, back, and chest and can be influenced by hormones, diet, and stress.

name: Acne & Rosacea
description: This category includes acne as well as rosacea, which causes facial redness, visible blood vessels, and sometimes acne-like bumps.

name: Actinic Keratosis / Skin Cancer
description: Precancerous lesions and malignant skin tumors caused by sun damage, including basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma.

name: Atopic Dermatitis
description: A chronic inflammatory skin condition causing itchy, red, and dry patches, often linked to allergies or genetic factors.

name: Bullous Disease
description: Rare disorders causing large, fluid-filled blisters, which can be inherited or autoimmune.

name: Carcinoma
description: Malignant skin tumors that can grow and spread if untreated.

name: Bacterial Infections
description: Skin infections caused by bacteria such as cellulitis, impetigo, and folliculitis.

name: Eczema
description: Red, itchy, and inflamed skin patches that may ooze or crust, commonly triggered by allergies or irritants.

name: Eczema
description: Red, itchy, and inflamed skin patches that may ooze or crust, commonly triggered by allergies or irritants.

name: Drug Eruptions
description: Skin reactions resulting from medications, often appearing as rashes, hives, or blisters.

name: HAM10000 Part 1
description: Part of the HAM10000 dataset for various skin lesions.

name: HAM10000 Part 2
description: Continuation of the HAM10000 dataset for skin lesion classification.

name: Hair Loss / Alopecia
description: Conditions leading to hair thinning, bald patches, or total hair loss due to genetics, autoimmune issues, or other causes.

name: Herpes / HPV / STDs
description: Viral infections affecting skin or mucous membranes, including herpes simplex, HPV warts, and other sexually transmitted diseases.

name: Keratosis
description: Thickened, scaly skin patches that can be benign or precancerous.

name: Pigmentation Disorders
description: Changes in skin color including hypopigmentation, hyperpigmentation, or light/dark spots.

name: Lupus / Connective Tissue
description: Autoimmune disorders affecting skin, causing rashes, lesions, and systemic symptoms.

name: Melanoma / Nevi / Moles
description: Abnormal or cancerous moles and skin lesions requiring careful monitoring.

name: Milia
description: Small white cysts commonly appearing on the face, especially around eyes and cheeks.

name: Nail Diseases
description: Fungal infections or other nail disorders causing discoloration, thickening, or brittleness.

name: Contact Dermatitis
description: Skin inflammation caused by contact with irritants or allergens such as poison ivy or chemicals.

name: Psoriasis / Lichen Planus
description: Chronic inflammatory skin diseases causing thick, scaly patches and redness.

name: Rosacea
description: Facial redness, visible blood vessels, and sometimes acne-like bumps, often triggered by heat or stress.

name: Infestations / Bites
description: Skin reactions caused by insect bites, ticks, scabies, or other parasitic infestations.

name: Seborrheic Keratoses
description: Noncancerous skin growths that appear waxy, wart-like, or slightly raised, common in older adults.

name: Systemic Disease
description: Skin symptoms that occur as a result of internal diseases or systemic conditions.

name: Fungal Infections
description: Skin infections caused by fungi such as ringworm, athlete’s foot, or candidiasis.

name: Urticaria / Hives
description: Raised, itchy welts on the skin caused by allergic reactions or other triggers.

name: Vascular Tumors
description: Abnormal growths of blood vessels in the skin, sometimes congenital or benign.

name: Vasculitis
description: Inflammation of blood vessels leading to red or purple skin lesions and potential systemic involvement.

name: Warts / Viral Infections
description: Viral infections causing warts, molluscum, or other lesions on skin.
